poem:
"To the Office Afoot"

No walkers but the vigorous
and ski-hidden in concrete drums.
Through sleet, by sun,
past boiler rooms breathing smoke,
we define our own highways.
Not swifter, but in imitating rivers,
flow to work. Payment? Not coin,
but heartbeats in the blood,
change acquired from transacting movement,
barter of muscle for horizon,
our commute, a statement of vitality.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Tell us: how do you make your commute fun or productive? Commuting isn’t normally associated with being fun or energetic, but some people have been taking a different approach to their journey to work by cycling, running or skiing. We would like to know how you make your commute productive or fun. Do you run or rollerblade into the office even though it takes longer than public transport? What prompted you to change how you". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
